</div>
</div>
<p>Perhaps the most famous Lincoln Presidential state car was a 1961 Lincoln Continental convertible, custom built by <a href="/wiki/Hess_%26_Eisenhardt" class="mw-redirect" title="Hess &amp; Eisenhardt">Hess &amp; Eisenhardt</a> of Cincinnati, and known as the <a href="/wiki/SS-100-X" title="SS-100-X">SS-100-X</a>, designed for use by <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy" title="John F. Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a>. Designed to be an open-top car to give the President better visibility and a better ability to interact with citizens, it also included a "<a href="/wiki/Poly(methyl_methacrylate)" title="Poly(methyl methacrylate)">plexiglas</a>" bubble top to be used in the event of inclement weather. The 1961 vehicle was notorious for its inadequate cooling of the rear of the passenger cabin while the bubble top was in place, particularly in sunshine. In order to prevent excessive heat and discomfort to the passengers, the top was often removed prior to parades. Kennedy notably used it when welcoming Ethiopian King Haile Selassie in several parades in DC and New York. (see image above) It was in the back of this car that Kennedy was <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">assassinated</a>.</p>
<p>Due to security concerns following Kennedy's assassination, it was temporarily removed from service. While it was once rumored<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (April 2013)">by whom?</span></a></i>]</sup> that Kennedy's successor, <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_Johnson" class="mw-redirect" title="Lyndon Johnson">Lyndon Johnson</a>, had ordered it destroyed, it instead was retrofitted with armor plating and a fixed, permanent sedan roof. It reentered service and was used by Johnson and his successor, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>. It was eventually retired in 1977 and is now on display at the <a href="/wiki/Henry_Ford_Museum" class="mw-redirect" title="Henry Ford Museum">Henry Ford Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dearborn,_Michigan" title="Dearborn, Michigan">Dearborn, Michigan</a>. The Johnson Administration also used three 1965 Lincoln Continental Executive limousines: Two limousines for the President and one for Secretary of Defense <a href="/wiki/Robert_McNamara" title="Robert McNamara">Robert McNamara</a>, as well as a 1968 "stretch" Lincoln to be used in Washington, D.C., and <a href="/wiki/Austin,_Texas" title="Austin, Texas">Austin, Texas</a>. This vehicle is on display at the <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_Baines_Johnson_Library_and_Museum" title="Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum">Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1969_Continental">1969 Continental</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lincoln_Motor_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: 1969 Continental">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1972_Presidential_Limousine,_Washington_DC.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/1972_Presidential_Limousine%2C_Washington_DC.JPG/220px-1972_Presidential_Limousine%2C_Washington_DC.JPG" width="220" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/1972_Presidential_Limousine%2C_Washington_DC.JPG/330px-1972_Presidential_Limousine%2C_Washington_DC.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/1972_Presidential_Limousine%2C_Washington_DC.JPG/440px-1972_Presidential_Limousine%2C_Washington_DC.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5777" data-file-height="4517" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1972_Presidential_Limousine,_Washington_DC.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
1969 Lincoln Continental used by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>A state car based on a 1969 Lincoln was commissioned for <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>. Constructed by Lehman-Peterson of Chicago, this vehicle also had an added sunroof so that Nixon could stand upright when appearing before parade-goers if desired. This vehicle was equipped with several features, such as retractable hand grips and running boards, options later copied by Hess &amp; Eisenhardt. This car is now located at the <a href="/wiki/Nixon_Library" class="mw-redirect" title="Nixon Library">Nixon Library</a> in Yorba Linda, California.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1972_Continental">1972 Continental</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lincoln_Motor_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: 1972 Continental">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The 1969 Continental would be replaced as the front-line state car in 1974 when Ford supplied a 1972 Continental model which was stretched to 22 feet (7&#160;m), outfitted with armor plating and bullet-resistant glass and powered by a 460&#160;cu&#160;in (7.5&#160;L) V8 engine. While intended for Nixon, it was instead used by his successor, <a href="/wiki/Gerald_Ford" title="Gerald Ford">Gerald Ford</a>, following <a href="/wiki/Watergate_scandal#Resignation" title="Watergate scandal">Nixon's resignation</a>. It was later used by <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>, until it was replaced by a <a href="/wiki/Cadillac_Fleetwood_Brougham" title="Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham">Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham</a> in 1983.</p>
<p>Like the SS-100-X, this state vehicle has lasting notoriety due to its presence at two assassination attempts against Presidents; it was used for a quick getaway by Gerald Ford following <a href="/wiki/Sara_Jane_Moore" title="Sara Jane Moore">Sara Jane Moore</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Sara_Jane_Moore#Attempted_assassination_of_Gerald_Ford" title="Sara Jane Moore">assassination attempt against him</a> in 1975, and most notably, at <a href="/wiki/John_Hinckley,_Jr." class="mw-redirect" title="John Hinckley, Jr.">John Hinckley, Jr.</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Reagan_assassination_attempt" class="mw-redirect" title="Reagan assassination attempt">assassination attempt against Ronald Reagan</a> in 1981. It was the armor plating on the car that wounded Reagan, as no shot directly hit him; the near-fatal shot that struck him had originally hit the side of the car and ricocheted off the bulletproof armor. Reagan was quickly plunged into the car, which transported him to <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_University" title="George Washington University">George Washington University</a> hospital. Today, the car is on display at the Henry Ford Museum alongside the Sunshine Special and SS-100-X.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1989_Town_Car">1989 Town Car</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lincoln_Motor_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: 1989 Town Car">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg/250px-George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg" width="250" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg/375px-George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg/500px-George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="468" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:George_H._W._Bush_presidential_limousine_1989.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A 1989 Town Car state vehicle used by <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The last Lincoln (as of 2016) to be used as a Presidential state car was a 1989 <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Town_Car" title="Lincoln Town Car">Lincoln Town Car</a> commissioned for <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a>. To compensate for the thick armor plating and bulletproof glass, the height of the roof was raised several inches. To compensate for the added weight, the chassis was fitted with a 460&#160;cu&#160;in (7.5&#160;L) EFI V8 coupled to a <a href="/wiki/Ford_C6_transmission#E4OD" title="Ford C6 transmission">E4OD</a> 4-speed automatic transmission; the powertrain was sourced from a Ford F-250 three-quarter ton pickup.</p>
<p>Upon its retirement when Bush left office in 1993, the 1989 Town Car became the last Lincoln vehicle to be used in the Presidential fleet. Today it is on display at the <a href="/wiki/George_Bush_Presidential_Library" title="George Bush Presidential Library">George Bush Presidential Library</a>. Subsequent Presidents <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> along with former President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> have used custom-built Cadillac vehicles as their state cars.</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
